Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Observations of carbon, water, and vegetation dynamics during and after the 2015/2016 El Nino drought to test models of climate-change induced Amazon forest 'dieback'
Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists are concerned that the great forests of the Amazon basin may be vulnerable to climate change. In the worst case, according to the predictions of some numerical models, climate change could cause large reductions in rainfall that could cause the collapse of Amazon forests. Critically needed to allow us to understand whether these models are realistic are observations of forest responses to real-world drought. This RAPID project will measure the amount of carbon dioxide from the air above the forest that is captured by the forest, along with measurements of tree growth and death during and after the unusually strong El Nino event that is now causing drought, high temperatures, and fires across the eastern region of the Amazon along the equator. The project will be carried out in collaboration with many Brazilian scientists and students who are also working at this location.

Net ecosystem exchange of carbon dioxide, latent heat and sensible head will be made from the km67 eddy flux tower in the Tapajós forest near the city of Santarém, Brazil. This site has the longest combined eddy flux and forest tree dynamics record in an Amazon forest (starting in 2001). It is an ideal location for this work because it is in one of the most El Nino-sensitive areas of the South American Amazon. Results will provide much needed information about the ecological mechanisms that underlie the forest collapse models that have received so much recent attention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Observations of carbon, water, and vegetation dynamics during and after the 2015/2016 El Nino drought to test mechanisms of climate-change induced Amazon forest 'dieback'

There is a increase public concern that the great forests of the Amazon basin may be vulnerable to changes in weather and climate. According to the predictions of some numerical models, expected temperature increase and large reductions in rainfall could lead to the collapse of Amazonian tropical forests. Other models assume increase growth due to CO2 fertilization which enables the plant to increase carbon uptake without increasing water loss via transpiration. Observations of forest responses to real-world drought are critically needed to allow us to understand whether these models are realistic. Measurements whole-ecosystem CO2 fluxes and forest dynamics (the growth and mortality of trees) during and after the unusually strong El Nino 2015-2016 were collected as part of this RAPID project and are key to understand future ecosystem response. The 2015 ENSO event was associated with anomalous low rain, high temperatures, and fires across eastern equatorial Amazônia. Observations were made at the “km67” eddy flux tower in the Tapajós forest near the city of Santarém, Brazil (see image). The Tapajós site, has the longest combined eddy flux and forest tree dynamics record in an Amazon forest (starting in 2001), and it was an ideal location for this work because it is located in one of the most El Nino-sensitive areas of the South American Amazon (Fig 1).

 

We found that: (1) the 2015-2016 ENSO was the third strongest event on record since 1950 (Fig 1-2); (2) precipitation decreased to 50% of the average annual, the dry-season was extended by 1-month and rainfall was 31.8 mm month-1 compared to a mean dry season precipitation of 62.8 mm month-1 (1998-2014) (Fig. 1-2); (3) the monthly average water vapour flux (LE) decreased by 20 W m-2 and the vegetation showed signs of stress by closing their stomatas and reducing the amount of CO2 uptake and transpiration (Fig. 3b and 4b) and (4) the sensible heat flux (H, the radiative flux was used in heating rather than in water evapotranspiration) reached sustained day-time daily values above 90 W m-2,reaching ~140 W m-2 -the highestseasonal day-time Hmeasured at the site(Fig 3a).The forest exhibited dramatic responses to ElNiño in carbon cycling,as well (Fig4). Large declines in ecosystem-scale photosynthetic activity (gross ecosystem productivity, GEP, Fig4b) were matched by large declines in ecosystem respiration (Fig4c) during the 2015-2016 ENSO (September 2015 - January 2016). Photosyntesis increased at the beginning of the dry season (GEPatFig.<

span>4

b). By contrast, ecosystem respiration was abnormally low during the entire ENSO event (Reco Fig. 4c). The resulting net ecosystem exchange (NEE = ecosystem respiration - GEP) show anomalous cycle, with enhanced uptake at the beginning of the 2015 dry season which falls to low values, before returning, anomalously, to net loss in the wet season (negative carbon flux) (Fig. 4a).

 

Our results give valuable information about the ecological mechanisms that underlie the 'forest collapse' models that have received so much attention, indicate that although resilient, the forest showed significant signs of stress (for the first time measured at this site), and inform future work at tropical forest ecosystems.
